channel.title: Why was there only middle ages in europe
channel.description:
Everyone knows that the whole middle ages took place in Europe. No where in, Canada, U.S.A, south america, south africa was there fighting going on with swords and knights and castles.
Atleast no documented ones. Discuss why the other continents remained dorment while battles raged on during these times.
Now, I don't know much, or anything about this topic but some guy called peter hurley, he does shows and tought kids about the middle ages, I remember when I was 10 and he still does do shows, but I never got around to finding the answer out. Anyways, he either said something about a long time ago (very long time, not 300 years) in iraq something happened and it changed his life forever, or that he found out a long time ago in iraq, most likely first one.

item.title: Why was there only middle ages in europe
item.dc:creator: @dragonfire455 dragonfire455
item.description:
@dragonfire455 wrote:

maybe cos the in europe, there was the myth of King Arthur, and so the name “Middle Ages” or “Dark Ages” began

Read full topic

item.title: Why was there only middle ages in europe
item.dc:creator: @billygotshot billygotshot
item.description:
@billygotshot wrote:

The Middle Ages was mainly about the Church being unfair and lying to the people… thus came the Renaissance and the Reformation… as far as i know china and other countries in the east were not under the Church rule…

Read full topic
item.source: Why was there only middle ages in europe

item.title: Why was there only middle ages in europe
item.dc:creator: @ThatOneServer Mike_
item.description:
@ThatOneServer wrote:

Anyways, the bottom line is that the middle ages had 100% to do with Christianity/Catholicism, and some areas were cut off from european contact.

Read full topic

item.title: Why was there only middle ages in europe
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

But the Dutch were allowed to enter Japan, because we didn’t care about religion, but our wallets.

Read full topic
item.source: Why was there only middle ages in europe

item.title: Why was there only middle ages in europe
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

Silver Lining:

Of course things were going on in other places. They just weren’t documented. In South America, they were all drinking ayahuasca. In North America, they were all eating calamus. In Africa, they were preparing themselves so they’d make good slaves.

ROFL.

the fu superior:

Silver lining, that wasn’t funny about the slaves.

Yes it was, lol.

On a side note, there was a Japanese isolation for a good 2 centuries, around 1600-1800 to prevent Christianity spreading.

Read full topic
item.source: Why was there only middle ages in europe

item.title: Why was there only middle ages in europe
item.dc:creator: @ThatOneServer Mike_
item.description:
@ThatOneServer wrote:

“The New World” was seperated from all technologies and beliefs from the “main land”.
The middle ages was a result of Catholicism, which did not exist in the “New World”. Therefore, it was impossible for there to be the same thing going on here.

Read full topic
item.source: Why was there only middle ages in europe

item.source: Why was there only middle ages in europe

item.title: Why was there only middle ages in europe
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“Cheese_Police, post:5, topic:176021”][quote author=Niall link=topic=236691.msg2014616#msg2014616 date=1201328952]
Europe wasn’t the only continent fighting, the New World was discovered by Christopher Columbus in 1493, and we don’t know a lot about what happened in the New World before this.
[/quote]

The “New World” was discovered long before Columbus found it. Perhaps you mean Columbus brought the discovery of the “New World” to Europe.[/quote]
Yes in 998 by the Icelander Leiv Eriksson.

Read full topic
